narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Introduction to epistemology, some early modern epistemology and more contemporary religious epistemology

I understood different models on which to ground epistemic belief, notably reformed epistemology. The most enlightening part of the class was the exploration of attacks on classical foundationalism, which is how most people go about forming beliefs (have set of prior beliefs, justify all further beliefs using evidence that map to prior beliefs.) It made me realize that what we confine ourselves to believing is reasonable is in fact rather narrow and artificial, and pushed me to become more open-minded in ways I didn't expect.
Ability to read philosophical texts and critically discuss them.
A knowledge of the field of epistemology, and an overview of the history of the field, as well as current debates.

I learned a lot about contemporary and past skeptical doubts and the responses to them. Additionally, I feel like I learned a philosophical way of thinking and arguing. Now when I hear an argument, I am immediately thinking about what premises it is based on and considering whether it might be self-defeating. At the same time, I also learned that ones reading of a work should work to interpret it as favorably as possible.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Great readings, nicely prepared handouts for the class, opportunities to ask questions
Weaknesses: Most often toward the latter half of the course, we would focus on a very specific aspect of a reading (that sometimes was not tied to the overall thesis of the work), and it might be helpful to receive advance notice to read that part carefully.

The more specialized topics about faith towards the end were by far the most interesting part of the course. The first half of the course is essentially building up fundamental ideas by early-modern philosophers, which might be a bit repetitive for certain students who already have that background from DS or otherwise.
The course wasn't very strictly structured, but the material was ordered well.
Prof. DeRose is extremely well-learned and an expert in the field; this was extremely helpful in the lecture. However, the lecture style was a bit dry.
It was great to hear Professor DeRoses perspectives, but I do also wish there was more time for student discussion of the works. I also loved reading the philosophical works we covered.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online live lecture was a close approximation of a regular class, but the lectures could have been recorded for later review.
N/A (it was largely unchanged from a standard lecture with Prof. DeRose)
The break halfway through lecture was very helpful and made it much easier to stay engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Professor DeRose teaches the class very well; he introduces epistemological concepts and terms and provides a nice survey and introduction to epistemology.

Yes, this is a good intro-level philosophy course that doesn't rely on previous knowledge of the material. Non-majors would likely enjoy the material and philosophy majors could use it as an opportunity to further their understanding of important issues in epistemology.
Advised for people with some background in philosophy; the technical language can be a tad difficult.
If you have an interest in basic epistemology i would totally recommend it, especially if you are new to philosophy! Just be aware that its not really a student-student discussion seminar.
Yes
